{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2013}} {{About|the American outlaw|the chairman of the British Electoral Commission, James Samuel Younger|Sam Younger}} {{Refimprove|date=June 2007}} {{Infobox person |name = Jim Younger |image = Jim Younger.jpg |caption = |birth_name = James Hardin Younger |birth_date = {{birth date|1848|01|15}} |birth_place = [[Lee's Summit, Missouri|Lee's Summit]], [[Jackson County, Missouri]], [[United States|USA]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1902|10|19|1848|01|15}} |death_place = [[St. Paul, Minnesota]], USA |other_names = |known_for = [[Banditry]] |occupation = |nationality = [[United States|American]] |spouse = |children = |parents = [[Henry Washington Younger]], [[Bersheba Leighton Fristoe]] }} [[File:JimMugshot.jpg|thumb|A wounded Jim Younger after his arrest in 1876]] '''James Hardin Younger''' (January 15, 1848 – October 19, 1902) was a notable American [[outlaw]] and member of the [[James–Younger Gang]]. He was the brother of [[Cole Younger|Cole]], [[John Younger|John]] and [[Bob Younger]]
==Life== Born in [[Missouri]] on January 15, 1848. Jim Younger was the ninth of fourteen children born to [[Henry Washington Younger]] and [[Bersheba Leighton Fristoe]]. With his brother Cole, he joined the Confederate Army during the [[American Civil War]], eventually becoming a member of [[Quantrill's Raiders]] in 1864. Jim was later captured by Union troops, in the same ambush that resulted in [[William Quantrill]]'s death, and was imprisoned until the war's end.
After the war Jim tried his hand at various activities, including starting a horse ranch. In 1873 he joined the James–Younger Gang, which was founded by Cole, along with [[Frank James|Frank]] and [[Jesse James]].
It's uncertain how much time he spent with the gang, but he was present when his brother John was killed by [[Pinkerton National Detective Agency|Pinkertons]] in [[Roscoe, Missouri]] in 1874. He left the gang and spent the next two years working a ranch in San Luis Obispo, California.
==Return to James–Younger Gang and death== Jim returned to the gang in time to join the ill-fated 1876 bank job in [[Northfield, Minnesota]]. Part of his jaw was shot off and he was captured and sentenced to life imprisonment. Along with Cole, he was paroled in 1901. After his release he became engaged to Alix Mueller, who had met him in prison 20 years after the Northfield robbery. Due to the terms of his parole, however, Jim couldn't marry. He committed suicide on October 19, 1902. His body was returned to [[Lee's Summit, Missouri]] for burial.
==Film and television depiction== In 1941, Younger was portrayed by actor [[Arthur Kennedy]] in the film ''[[Bad Men of Missouri]]''.
In 1950, [[Dewey Martin (actor)|Dewey Martin]] played Younger in the film ''[[ Kansas Raiders]]'', about his time spent with [[Quantrill's Raiders]].
In 1954, [[Sheb Wooley]] played Younger in an episode of [[Jim Davis (actor)|Jim Davis]]'s [[Television syndication|syndicated]] [[Western (genre)|western]] [[television series]], ''[[Stories of the Century]]''.
In the 1972 film ''[[The Great Northfield Minnesota Raid]]'' he was portrayed by [[Luke Askew]]''.
In the 1980 film ''[[The Long Riders]]'' he was portrayed by [[Keith Carradine]].
In the TV show ''[[Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman]]'', he was portrayed in the episode "[[Baby Outlaws S3E21]]" by [[Donnie Jeffcoat]]
In the 2001 film ''[[American Outlaws]]'' he was portrayed by [[Gregory Smith (actor)|Gregory Smith]].
==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.civilwarstlouis.com/History/jamesgangoutlaws.htm James-Younger gang] at civilwarstlouis.com
==External links== *[http://www.ericjames.org Younger family genealogy on the official website for the family of Jesse James: Stray Leaves, A James Family in America Since 1650] *[http://www.mnhs.org/library/tips/history_topics/16northfield.html Minnesota Historical Society History Topics: Northfield Raid and James-Younger Gang]

{{about|the Scottish footballer}} {{distinguish|Jimmy Miller}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Jimmy Millar | fullname = James Millar | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1934|11|20|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Edinburgh]], Scotland | death_date = | height = {{convert|5|ft|6|in|abbr=on}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Centre forward]] | youthyears1 = 1950–1952 | youthclubs1 = Merchiston Thistle | years1 = 1952–1955 | years2 = 1955–1967 | years3 = 1967–1969 | clubs1 = [[Dunfermline Athletic F.C.|Dunfermline Athletic]] | clubs2 = [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] | clubs3 = [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] | caps1 = 43 | caps2 = 197 | caps3 = 18 | goals1 = 22 | goals2 = 91 | goals3 = 3 | totalcaps = 258 | totalgoals = 117 | nationalyears1 = 1961–1964 | nationalteam1 = [[Scottish League XI]]{{cite web|url=http://www.londonhearts.com/SFL/players/james2millar.html|title=Scottish League XI player profile|publisher=London Hearts Supports Club|accessdate=3 January 2018}} | nationalcaps1 = 4 | nationalgoals1 = 3 | nationalyears2 = 1963 | nationalteam2 = [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] | nationalcaps2 = 2 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | managerclubs1 = [[Raith Rovers F.C.|Raith Rovers]] | manageryears1 = 1969–1970 }} '''James Millar''' (born 20 November 1934 in [[Edinburgh]]) is a retired [[Association football|footballer]] who played for [[Dunfermline Athletic F.C.|Dunfermline Athletic]], [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] and [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]], mainly as a [[Forward (association football)|centre forward]]. ==Playing career== ===Club=== Born in [[Edinburgh]], Millar was signed by Rangers manager [[Scot Symon]] for £5000 on 12 January 1955 from Dunfermline Athletic, where he had played as a [[Midfielder|half back]] and also played in that position on a number of occasions in the early seasons of his career at [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox]]. Millar achieved more success when he played at centre forward in a pre-season tour of America and started scoring goals regularly. Millar was an integral part of the Rangers team of the early 1960s, alongside players such as [[Bobby Shearer]], [[Eric Caldow]], [[Davie Wilson]], [[John Greig]], [[Jim Baxter]] and [[Alex Scott (footballer born 1937)|Alex Scott]]. Millar had a highly successful strike partnership with fellow Edinburgh native [[Ralph Brand]] during this time. Despite not being particularly tall, he was renowned for his heading ability and bravery. Millar's total of 30 goals in the [[Scottish Cup]] is a post-war record for Rangers, equalled only by [[Derek Johnstone]], and on two occasions he scored twice in Scottish Cup finals, in [[Scottish Cup 1959-60|1960]] and [[Scottish Cup 1963-64|1964]],{{cite web|url=https://rangers.co.uk/news/features/classic-match-dundee-1964/|title=Classic matches: Rangers 3–1 Dundee, April 1964|publisher=Rangers F.C.|date=|accessdate=3 January 2018}} another record equalled only by Johnstone. Millar was the first ever [[substitute (football)|substitute]] to come on for Rangers, replacing [[Jim Forrest (footballer born 1944)|Jim Forrest]] during a 5–0 victory over [[Falkirk F.C.|Falkirk]] in a league match at Ibrox in October 1966. Millar was also known for his scoring record against Rangers' arch-rivals [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]], with 13 goals in [[Old Firm]] matches, including two winning goals at [[Celtic Park]] in the traditional New Year's Day fixture, in 1960 and 1964. Millar made 317 appearances (197 in the league) for Rangers, scoring 162 goals (91 in the league) and also won three Championships, five [[Scottish Cup]]s and three [[Scottish League Cup]]s. In the summer of 1967, Millar left Rangers for [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] and became manager of [[Raith Rovers F.C.|Raith Rovers]] for a brief spell after retiring, before owning a hostelry in [[Leith]]. Millar is a member of the [[List of Rangers F.C. players#Hall of fame|Rangers Hall of Fame]].{{cite news|url=http://rangers.co.uk/club/history/hall-of-fame/jimmy-millar/|title=Hall of Fame Profile: Jimmy Millar|date=|accessdate=31 March 2016|publisher=[[Rangers F.C.]]}} ===International=== Millar earned two [[Cap (sports)|caps]] for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] in 1963 during his spell with Rangers. He also featured four times for the [[Scottish League XI]], scoring three goals. ==Personal life== In 2017, Millar's family revealed that for the past decade Jimmy had been suffering from [[dementia]], a condition they believed to be linked to his heading a football.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/family-rangers-legend-jimmy-millar-10514094|title=Family of Rangers legend Jimmy Millar reveal his secret battle with dementia|newspaper=Daily Record|date=28 May 2017|accessdate=3 January 2018}} ==Honours== '''[[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]]'''{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/rangers/player.php?playerid=1487|title=Rangers player profile|publisher=Fitbastats.com|accessdate=3 January 2018}} *'''[[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]]'''
Runners-up: [[1960–61 European Cup Winners' Cup|1960–61]] *'''[[Scottish League First Division]] (3)''': [[1960–61 Scottish Division One|1960–61]], [[1962–63 Scottish Division One|1962–63]], [[1963–64 Scottish Division One|1963–64]] *'''[[Scottish Cup]] (5)''': [[1959–60 Scottish Cup|1959–60]], [[1961–62 Scottish Cup|1961–62]], [[1962–63 Scottish Cup|1962–63]], [[1963–64 Scottish Cup|1963–64]], [[1965–66 Scottish Cup|1965–66]] *'''[[Scottish League Cup]] (3)''': [[1960-61 Scottish League Cup|1960–61]], [[1961-62 Scottish League Cup|1961–62]], [[1964-65 Scottish League Cup|1964–65]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{SFA profile}} * {{NeilBrownPlayers|player/jimmymillar}} {{Scottish First Division top scorers}} {{Raith Rovers F.C. managers}} {{Rangers F.C. Hall of Fame}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Millar, Jimmy}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Edinburgh]] [[Category:Association football forwards]] [[Category:Dunfermline Athletic F.C. players]] [[Category:Dundee United F.C. players]] [[Category:Raith Rovers F.C. managers]] [[Category:Rangers F.C. players]] [[Category:Scotland international footballers]] [[Category:Scottish Football League managers]] [[Category:Scottish Football League players]] [[Category:Scottish Football League representative players]] [[Category:Scottish football managers]] [[Category:Scottish footballers]] [[Category:Scottish league football top scorers]] [[Category:People with dementia]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix = | name = John Austin | honorific-suffix = | image = | office = [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]]
for [[Erith and Thamesmead (UK Parliament constituency)|Erith and Thamesmead]]
[[Woolwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Woolwich]] (1992–1997) | parliament = | majority = | predecessor = [[John Cartwright (British politician)|John Cartwright]] | successor = [[Teresa Pearce]] | term_start = 10 April 1992 | term_end = 12 April 2010 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1944|08|21}} | birth_place = [[Blaby|Blaby, Leicestershire]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = British | spouse = | party = [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | religion = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''John Eric Austin''' (born 21 August 1944), formerly '''Austin-Walker''', is a [[Labour Party (UK)|British Labour Party]] politician, who was the Member of Parliament (MP) for [[Woolwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Woolwich]] from [[United Kingdom general election, 1992|1992]] to [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997]] and for [[Erith and Thamesmead (UK Parliament constituency)|Erith and Thamesmead]] from [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997]] to [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010]]. ==Early life== He attended the Glyn Grammar School for Boys (now called [[Glyn School]]) on The Kingsway in [[Epsom]]. Austin gained a Certificate in Community and Youth Work{{cite web|url=http://www.goldsmiths.ac.uk/pace/community-work.php |title=Community & Youth Work, Goldsmiths, University of London |publisher=Goldsmiths.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=12 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080617103416/http://www.goldsmiths.ac.uk/pace/community-work.php |archivedate=17 June 2008 |df= }} from [[Goldsmiths, University of London|Goldsmith's College]] in 1972 and a Master of Arts in Policy Studies{{cite web|url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/sps/ |title=Bristol University | School for Policy Studies |publisher=Bristol.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=12 February 2011}} from the [[University of Bristol]] in 1990. He worked as a medical laboratory technician from 1961–3, a Labour Party [[organiser (party)|organiser]] from 1963–70, a social worker in Bexley from 1972–4 before becoming Director of Bexley Councilhttp://www.bexleycre.org.uk {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206084200/http://www.bexleycre.org.uk/ |date=6 December 2008 }} for Racial Equality until 1992. Austin became a [[councillor]] for the [[Royal Borough of Greenwich|London Borough of Greenwich]] in 1970, and was leader of the council from 1982 to 1987, when he became mayor for two years. He stepped down as a councillor in 1994. ==Parliamentary career== Austin stood for the seat of [[Woolwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Woolwich]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1992|1992 general election]], and won it from independent [[John Cartwright (British politician)|John Cartwright]] with a majority of 2,225.{{cite web|url=http://www.psr.keele.ac.uk/area/uk/ge92/i22.htm |title=University of Keele – Political Science Resources – UK General Election results April 1992 |publisher=Psr.keele.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=12 February 2011}} The [[constituency]] boundaries for the area were re-drawn for [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]], and Austin won the new seat of Erith and Thamesmead with a majority of 17,424. Austin served as a member of the [[Health Select Committee]] from 1994 until 2005. He served on the Parliamentary [[Joint Committee on Human Rights]]. In May 2005 Austin threatened to stand as a [[stalking horse]] candidate against [[Tony Blair]].{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/stalkinghorse-threat-to-oust-blair-490152.html |work=The Independent |title='Stalking-horse' threat to oust Blair|date=10 May 2005 |accessdate = 8 March 2010|location=London | first=Andrew | last=Grice}} He intended to trigger a leadership election at the [[Labour Party Conference|party conference]] in September 2005 if Blair himself did not do so by resigning as leader. He indicated his hope that, in the event of a contest, [[Gordon Brown]] would enter and win. However he was unable to accumulate the number of required nominations from fellow [[Member of Parliament|MPs]] to force a contest. Austin, a member of the left-wing [[Socialist Campaign Group]], announced his retirement in July 2008. He told a meeting of the General Council of the Erith & Thamesmead Constituency Labour Party that he would not run again at the next general election.{{cite news|title=John Austin MP to retire|url=http://www.epolitix.com/mpwebsites/mppressreleases/mppressreleasedetails/newsarticle/john-austin-mp-to-retire///mpsite/10763/?no_cache=1|work=ePolitix|date=31 July 2008|accessdate=2 August 2008}} Austin was implicated in the 2009 [[MPs' expenses scandal]], he claimed a total of £133,000 in second home allowances since 2001, despite the fact the two London flats he lived in over the period were just over 10 miles away from his main residence in Kent.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8056591.stm|title= Party whips face expenses focus|work=BBC News|accessdate=19 May 2009|date=19 May 2009|location=London}} However Austin has said his claims had been reasonable and within the rules. He is also a patron of [[Humanists UK]] (formerly known as the British Humanist Association).{{cite web |url=http://www.humanism.org.uk/about/people/distinguished-supporters |title=Distinguished Supporters |publisher=www.humanism.org.uk |accessdate=4 May 2010 }} ==Personal life== Austin lists his interests as running, cookery, and gardening. He married Linda in 1965. They have two sons Damien and Toby and a daughter Zoe, and divorced in 1988. Zoe gave him three grandchildren, Felix, Matilda and Kitty. Toby has given him three grandsons, Jake, Cameron and Ziggy. Damien has two sons. On 15 September 2010, Austin, along with 54 other public figures, signed an open letter published in ''[[The Guardian]]'', stating their opposition to [[Pope Benedict XVI]]'s state visit to the UK.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/sep/15/harsh-judgments-on-pope-religion|title=Letters: Harsh judgments on the pope and religion|work=The Guardian|accessdate=16 September 2010 | location=London | date=15 September 2010}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Hansard-contribs | mr-john-austin-walker | John Austin}} {{one source|date=May 2017}} {{refimprove|date=May 2017}} [[File:5 Cheyne Walk 01.JPG|thumb|[[5 Cheyne Walk]]]]
'''John Camden Neild''' (1780–1852) was an English [[miser]].
==Life== Neild, son of [[James Neild]], prison reformer, was probably born in St. James's Street, London, about 1780. He was educated at [[Eton College|Eton]] from 1793 to 1797, then at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], graduating in 1801, and being awarded his honorary M.A. three years later, as is standard at Cambridge.<ref>{{acad|id=NLT796JC|name=Neild, John Camden}}</ref> On 9 Feb. 1808 he was called to the bar at [[Lincoln's Inn]].
Succeeding in 1814 to the whole of his father's property, estimated at £250,000, he developed into a confirmed miser, and the last thirty years of his life were solely employed in accumulating wealth. He lived in a large house, [[5 Cheyne Walk]], Chelsea, but it was so meanly furnished that for some time he had not a bed to lie on. His dress consisted of a blue swallow-tailed coat with gilt buttons, brown trousers, short gaiters, and shoes which were patched and generally down at the heels. He never allowed his clothes to be brushed, because, he said, it destroyed the nap. He continually visited his numerous estates, walking whenever it was possible, never went to the expense of a great-coat, and always stayed with his tenants, sharing their coarse meals and lodging. While at [[North Marston]], in Buckinghamshire, about 1828 he attempted to cut his throat, and his life was only saved by the prompt attention of his tenant's wife, Mrs. Neale. Unlike other eminent misers – Daniel Dancer or [[John Elwes (politician)|John Elwes]] – he occasionally indulged in acts of benevolence, possessed considerable knowledge of legal and general literature, and to the last retained a love for the classics.
He died at 5 Cheyne Walk, Chelsea, 30 Aug. 1852, aged 72, and was buried in the chancel of North Marston Church on 9 Sept. By his will, after bequeathing a few trifling legacies, he left the whole of his property, estimated at £500,000, to ‘[[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Her Most Gracious Majesty Queen Victoria]], begging Her Majesty's most gracious acceptance of the same for her sole use and benefit.’ Two caveats were entered against the will, but were subsequently withdrawn. Queen Victoria increased Neild's bequests to the three executors from £100 to £1,000 each, she provided for his servants, for whom he made no provision, and she secured an annuity of £100 to Mrs. Neale, who had frustrated Neild's attempt at suicide. In 1855 Queen Victoria restored the chancel of North Marston Church and inserted a window to Neild's memory.
==References== {{reflist}} ;Attribution * {{DNB|wstitle=Neild, John Camden}}

Use image_upright. --> | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> | birth_date = May 28, 1832 | birth_place = Belfort, France | baptised = <!-- will not display if birth_date is entered --> | disappeared_date = <!-- {{disappeared date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (disappeared date then birth date) --> | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = December 11, 1915 | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | burial_place = <!-- may be used instead of resting_place and resting_place_coordinates (displays "Burial place" as label) --> | burial_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = France | other_names = | citizenship = France and USA | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | era = | employer = | organization = [[Joseph Fahys & Co.]], Alvin Manufacturing Co., Brooklyn Watch Case Co., Sea View Elevated Railroad Co., and Victoria Fire Insurance Co. | agent = <!-- Discouraged in most cases, specifically when promotional, and requiring a reliable source --> | known_for = | notable_works = <!-- produces label "Notable work"; may be overridden by |credits=, which produces label "Notable credit(s)"; or by |works=, which produces label "Works" --> | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- "X cm", "X m" or "X ft Y in" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | weight = <!-- "X kg", "X lb" or "X st Y lb" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = Jewelers' Board of Trade (President), Watchcase Manufacturers' Association (President), Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, Union League, Downtown Association, Homoeopathic Hospital Lafayette Avenue, Presbyterian Church and Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = <!-- Use article title or common name --> | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> | children = George Ernest Fahys | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | mother = Marianne Moulleseaux Fahys | father = Joseph Fahys | relatives = | family = | callsign = | awards = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }}
'''Joseph Fahys''' (May 28, 1832 – December 11, 1915) was one of the first U.S. [[watch#Parts|watch case]] manufacturers. After emigrating from France, he went on to establish [[Joseph Fahys & Co.]], which at one time was the largest manufacturer of watch cases and one of the largest manufacturers of [[Silver (household)|silverware]] in the United States.<ref name="Leonard1922">{{cite book|last=Leonard|first=John William|title=Who's who in finance and banking|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r-8ZAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA150|accessdate=31 October 2011|edition=Public domain|year=1922|publisher=Who's Who in Finance Inc.|pages=150–}}</ref> He was also the founder and first president of the [[Jewelers' Board of Trade]], and the first president of the Watchcase Manufacturers' Association.
==Early years== Fahys was born on May 28, 1832 in [[Belfort]], France. He was the son of Joseph and Marianne Moulleseaux Fahys.<ref name="Collectors2001">{{cite book|author=National Association of Watch and Clock Collectors|title=NAWCC bulletin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nkIeAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=31 October 2011|year=2001|publisher=National Association of Watch and Clock Collectors, Inc.}}</ref> His father was a contractor; and both his father and brother died when Fahys was young. In company with his mother, he came to New York in March, 1848. He apprenticed himself to Ulysses Savoye (or Ulyses S. Savage), of [[West Hoboken, New Jersey]], one of the two first makers of watch cases in the United States. He remained in Savoye's employ for five years, and soon after attaining his majority, began what an independent career.<ref name="HowardJervis1893">{{cite book|last1=Howard|first1=Henry Ward Beecher|last2=Jervis|first2=Arthur N.|title=The Eagle and Brooklyn|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SUsMAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1017|accessdate=31 October 2011|edition=Public domain|year=1893|publisher=The Brooklyn daily eagle|pages=1017–}}</ref>
==Career== Fahys bought out the Savoye business on June 1, 1857. He continued it under his own name and moved the factory to the fourth floor of 75 [[Nassau Street (Manhattan)|Nassau Street]], New York City before later moving the plant to [[Carlstadt, New Jersey]].<ref name="The Jewelers' circular">{{cite book|title=The Jewelers' circular|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tFUcAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA183|accessdate=31 October 2011|edition=Public domain|date=April 30, 1919|publisher=Jewelers' Circular Co.|pages=183–}}</ref> In 1861, he formed a connection with [[Fortenbach Brothers]] (John, Jacob, and Joseph),<ref name="ClaytonNelson1882">{{cite book|last1=Clayton|first1=W. Woodford|last2=Nelson|first2=William|title=History of Bergen and Passaic counties, New Jersey: with biographical sketches of many of its pioneers and prominent men|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zDEUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA228|accessdate=31 October 2011|edition=Public domain|year=1882|publisher=Everts & Peck|pages=228–}}</ref> which resulted in the building at Carlstadt, one of the first establishments in America which manufactured watch cases on an extensive scale; for five years, business was profitable. In 1867, Fahys located a similar factory in Brooklyn in which he associated with Wheeler, Parsons & Hayes, and the joint enterprise was known as the Brooklyn Watch Case Company. When both factories were well under way, Fahys sold his New York store to Ward & Jennings, two of his employees, and gave his undivided attention to his manufacturing interests. In 1876, he bought the share of the Fortenbach Brothers and moved the Carlstadt plant to Sag Harbor, Long Island.<ref name="HowardJervis1893" /> For many years he made a specialty of silver watch cases.<ref name="The Jewelers' circular" />
He was president of [[Joseph Fahys & Co.]], located in the Fahys Building, on 54 [[Maiden Lane (Manhattan)|Maiden Lane]], [[New York City]]; the company was established in 1857.<ref name="Jewelers1897">{{cite book|author=Jewelers' Circular|title=The jewelers' circular and horological review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RHUoAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA28|accessdate=31 October 2011|edition=Public domain|volume=XXXIV; No. 14|date=May 5, 1897|publisher=Jewelers' Circular Pub. Co.|pages=28–}}</ref> Fahys' son-in-law,<ref name="MacKayBaker1997">{{cite book|last1=MacKay|first1=Robert B.|last2=Baker|first2=Anthony K.|last3=Traynor|first3=Carol A.|title=Long Island country houses and their architects, 1860-1940|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jIXc9ES8qcAC&pg=PT187|accessdate=31 October 2011|date=11 April 1997|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|isbn=978-0-393-03856-9|pages=187–}}</ref> Henry Francis Cook, who was president of the [[Montauk Steamboat Company]], became a partner of Fays & Co. in 1880. In 1887, in connection with A. N. Darling, Hayden W. Wheeler, Lewis A. Parsons and Henry Hays, he founded the Brooklyn Watch Case Co. for the manufacture of solid gold cases and retained a dominant interest in this for many years though he devoted his time principally to his own factory at Sag Harbor.<ref name="The Jewelers' circular" />
Fahys was the founder and first president of the Jewelers' Board of Trade, and the first president of the Watchcase Manufacturers' Association. He was a member of the [[Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York]], the [[Union League]], and the Downtown Association. He was a trustee of the Homoeopathic Hospital, the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church,<ref name="HowardJervis1893" /> and the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences. He was director of the Alvin Manufacturing Co., Brooklyn Watch Case Co., Sea View Elevated Railroad Co., and Victoria Fire Insurance Co.<ref name="Biographical1900">{{cite book|author=Biographical directory Co.|title=Biographical directory of the state of New York, 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hns_AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA130|accessdate=31 October 2011|edition=Public domain|year=1900|publisher=Biographical directory company (incorporated)|pages=130–}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 1856, he married a lady who was a native of Sag Harbor. Their son, George Ernest Fahys, who became a partner in the Fahys Co., was born in West Hoboken in 1864. Fahys's daughter, Lena Marianne, married Cook in 1883.<ref name="HowardJervis1893" />
Fahys and Cook purchased one thousand acres of land in [[North Haven, New York|North Haven]], a suburb of Sag Harbor, with two miles of frontage on [[Peconic Bay]].<ref name="Ross1903">{{cite book|last=Ross|first=Peter|title=A history of Long Island: from its earliest settlement to the present time|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6T_ubA4oBXgC&pg=PA30|accessdate=31 October 2011|edition=Public domain|year=1903|publisher=The Lewis publishing company|pages=30–}}</ref> Fahys' [[Clinton Hill, Brooklyn]] residences were designed in 1889 and 1890 by [[Benjamin Wistar Morris, III]]. Morris also designed Fahys' [[Long Island]] country house.<ref name="MacKayBaker1997" /> Fahys also lived in New York City on [[Park Avenue]]. He died at his summer home in [[Sag Harbor, New York|Sag Harbor, Long Island]].<ref name="nytimes.com1915">{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F3061EFC355C13738DDDAD0994DA415B858DF1D3|title=Joseph Fahys - Obituary|date=December 14, 1915|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

{{Infobox model | name = Kimora Lee Leissner | image = KimoraLeeSimmons at Push Premiere.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Leissner at the [[Push (2009 film)|Push]] premiere in January 2009 | birth_name = Kimora Lee Perkins{{cite web|title=Kimora Lee Leissner Biography|url=http://www.biography.com/people/kimora-lee-simmons-504534|publisher=biography.com}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1975|5|4}} | birth_place = [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], U.S. | yearsactive = 1992–present | death_date = | death_place = | height = {{height|ft=6|in=0}} | haircolor = Dark brown | eyecolor = Brown | spouse = {{marriage|[[Russell Simmons]]
|1998|2009|end=div}}
{{marriage|Tim Leissner
|2013}} | partner = [[Djimon Hounsou]] (2007–2012) | children = 4 | website = {{URL|http://www.kimoraleesimmons.com/}} }} '''Kimora Lee Leissner''' (''née'' '''Perkins''', formerly '''Simmons'''; born May 4, 1975)[http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,631589,00.html Russell's hip-hip birthday gift] (April 26, 2004) ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''. Accessed 2008-02-19. is an American [[fashion model]] and [[fashion designer]]. She took over [[Baby Phat]] after Russell Simmons and was CEO/creative director through 2010. She had her own reality television shows ''[[Kimora: Life in the Fab Lane]]'' (2007–2011) and ''Kimora: House of Fab'' (2013). ==Early life and education== Kimora Lee Perkins was born in [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]].[http://www.thebookstandard.com/bookstandard/reviews/books_in_news_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1001882919 'Fabulosity,' by Kimora Lee Simmons] (review January 22, 2006) ''TheBookStandard.com''. Accessed 2007-12-20. Her mother, Joanne "Kyoko" Perkins,[http://www.tvoneonline.com/shows/show.asp?sid=123 'TV One on One' with Cathy Hughes] (original airdate March 25, 2007) ''Tv One''. Accessed 2010-01-29. was born in Korea to a Japanese mother and adopted by a U.S. serviceman during the [[Korean War]] and raised in the U.S. She later worked as an administrator for [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]]. Kimora's father is African American. Her father, Vernon Whitlock Jr., worked as a Federal Marshal, an Equal Employment Opportunity Commission investigator, a [[bail bondsman]], and later became a [[barber]] in St. Louis.Phoebe Eaton (June 14, 2004) [http://nymag.com/nymetro/shopping/fashion/features/9306/index2.html Kimora Lee Simmons, the New Queen of Conspicuous Consumption] ''New York Magazine''. Accessed 2007-12-20. He was sentenced to prison when Kimora was in grade school for distribution of narcotics. It was substantiated in the U.S. District Court (Honorable Clyde Cahill) that government agents attempted to recruit Whitlock as an informant in exchange for probation, but he vehemently refused. Consequently, he was refused probation and was taken off his $500,000 bond and was given the 24-year sentence; he was released after five years. Her parents split up and she was raised by her mother.[http://www.celebritybabyscoop.com/2009/08/20/kimora-lee-simmons-my-kids-make-my-world-go-round "Kimora Lee Simmons: “My Kids Make My World Go ‘Round”"]. August 2009. Growing up in the northern St. Louis suburb of [[Florissant, Missouri]], Kimora was the target of schoolyard bullying and teasing, because of her height (she was {{height|ft=5|in=10|abbr=mos}} tall by the time she was 10 years old)Galina Espinoza (July 1, 2002). [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20137428,00.html Phat Cats]. ''People''. Accessed 2009-03-02. and mixed ancestry. To give her confidence because of her height, Simmons's mother enrolled her in a [[fashion modeling|modeling]] class when she was eleven years old. Two years later she was discovered by Marie-Christine Kollock (a representative for seminal Paris Agency Glamour) at a Model Search in Kansas City (organized by Kay Mitchell) and sent to [[Paris]]. Simmons is a graduate of [[Lutheran High School North (Missouri)|Lutheran North High School]] in [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]].{{Cite web|url=http://biography.jrank.org/pages/2705/Simmons-Kimora-Lee-Modeled-Teenager.html|title=Kimora Lee Simmons - Modeled As A Teenager|website=biography.jrank.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-02}} ==Career== ===Modeling=== [[File:Kimora Lee in Kouture.jpg|thumb|Kimora Lee on the runway, wearing a red dress by Kouture, 2010]] Just after her fourteenth birthday, Perkins was awarded an exclusive modeling contract with [[Chanel]] and went to work under the tutelage of Chanel designer [[Karl Lagerfeld]]. She quickly gained attention in the fashion world when she closed Lagerfeld's [[haute couture]] show in 1989. "Everything people thought was weird about me before", Perkins told ''[[People Weekly]]'', "was now good". Perkins soon walked for designers including [[Fendi]], [[Valentino SpA|Valentino]], [[Emanuel Ungaro]] and [[Yves Saint Laurent (brand)|Yves Saint Laurent]]. Perkins has been featured on the cover of the German, Indonesian, Singaporean and Malaysian editions of ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]''.{{cite news|title=Kimora Lee Simmons|url=http://www.fashionmodeldirectory.com/models/kimora_lee+simmons/|work=Fashion Model Directory|accessdate=20 July 2015}} ===Designing=== In 2004, Simmons' then husband [[Russell Simmons]] sold his clothing line [[Phat Farm]] to Kellwood Company for $140 million. When Russell stepped down as CEO of Phat Fashions LLC in September 2007, Simmons—who was already creative director of [[Baby Phat]] (which was a branch off Phat Farm Industries)—was promoted by Kellwood to President and Creative Director of Phat Fashions. It was her goal to turn fashion label [[Baby Phat]], launched in 1999, into an "aspirational lifestyle brand".[http://abcnews.go.com/2020/business/story?id=1362780 Lee's 'Fabulosity']. (December 2, 2005) ''ABC News 20/20''. Accessed 2009-05-21. Her high-end sportswear line, KLS, launched in fall 2007.Julee Greenberg (February 1, 2007) [http://www.wwd.com/media/issues/2007/02/01/issue-81145.pdf The Dressy Side of Kimora] (page 10) ''WWD''. Accessed 2009-05-21. On September 1, 2010, Simmons parted ways with Baby Phat and its management company, Kellwood.{{cite news|title=Kimora Lee's split from Baby Phat wasn't amicable; 'It's very, very sad for me,' she says at FNO|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2010-09-11/gossip/27075071_1_fashion-show-kimora-lee-baby-phat|work=NY Daily News |accessdate=2011-04-11|location=New York|date=September 11, 2010}} The details as to why Simmons was removed as creative director have not been clear; some blog sites claimed it was because Simmons was spending too much money on company pursuits and giving too much pay to herself and her children.{{cite news|title=Kimora Lee Simmons 'dumped' from Baby Phat|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/phat_blindsided_kimora_oySW8hmUnOZmu4Fd86AiyL?CMP=OTC-rss&FEEDNAME=|work=New York Post|publisher=New York Post|accessdate=2011-04-11|date=August 25, 2010}} After the split, Simmons planned to launch her KLS collection and Kouture by Kimora Brands. She had an exclusive brand coming to [[Macy's]] that would offer stylish clothes for under $40. On September 14, 2011, Simmons announced on her website that she was the new creative director and president of [[JustFab]], a personalized shopping website.[http://kls.com/i-have-exciting-news-09-2011 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926013745/http://kls.com/i-have-exciting-news-09-2011 |date=September 26, 2011 }} She ended her employment with [[JustFab]] in May 2015.{{cite web|url=https://instagram.com/p/23nK6QIIDi/?taken-by=officialkimora |title=Instagram |publisher=Instagram |date= |accessdate=2015-10-27}}{{cite web|url=https://instagram.com/p/21ZJ2QoIAF/?taken-by=officialkimora |title=Instagram |publisher=Instagram |date= |accessdate=2015-10-27}} In June 2015, Simmons relaunched her KLS label as a high end line, opening its first boutique in [[Beverly Hills]]. In 2016, the line began being carried at [[Bloomingdale's]] in the [[Aventura Mall]].{{cite news|last=Brinkley|first=Christina|title=Kimora Lee Simmons Launches a New Fashion Brand for Working Mothers |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/kimora-lee-simmons-launches-a-new-fashion-brand-for-working-mothers-1435791342|work=[[Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=2015-07-24|location=New York|date=July 1, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Goltzman|first=Jilian|title=5 Surprising Facts About Kimora Lee Simmons|url=http://www.miami.com/5-surprising-facts-about-kimora-lee-simmons-article|work=Miami.com |accessdate=2016-05-01}} ===Acting=== Simmons has appeared in small roles in television and films including ''[[Beauty Shop]]'', ''[[Brown Sugar (2002 film)|Brown Sugar]]'', and ''[[Waist Deep]]''. She has also appeared in music videos for [[Ginuwine]], [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]] and [[Rich Gang]] in the 2013 song "[[Tapout (song)|Tapout]]". In 2003, Simmons appeared as one of the judges on ''[[America's Next Top Model, Cycle 1]]''. She was scheduled to return but later chose not to.[http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2009/11/12/2009-11-12_top_model_to_get_major_makeover_with_kimora_lee_simmons_as_new_judge.html 'Top Model' to get major makeover with Kimora Lee Simmons as new judge]. (November 12, 2009) ''Daily News''. Accessed 2011-10-10.{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/daily/fashion/2009/12/kimora_lee_simmons_wont_judge.html|title=Kimora Lee Simmons Won't Judge America's Next Top Model|date=December 16, 2009|publisher=''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]''|accessdate=2010-02-09}} She has been a co-host of [[Sony Pictures Television|Sony Television]]'s syndicated talk show ''Life & Style''. On August 5, 2007, season one of her reality TV show, ''[[Kimora: Life in the Fab Lane]]'', premiered on [[Style Network]]. The show chronicles her daily life and routine as a mother and then-CEO of Phat Fashions. ===Other ventures=== Simmons wrote a self-help book, ''Fabulosity: What It Is and How to Get It'', that was published by [[HarperEntertainment]] in February 2006. The book is set to function as a 'lifestyle manual' on everything from spirituality and finances to fashion and beauty. She has also launched five perfumes for women: ''Goddess'', ''Golden Goddess'', ''Seductive Goddess'', ''Baby Phat Fabulosity'', ''Love me'', and the last fragrance she put out from her time with Baby Phat, ''Dare Me''. Simmons sponsored the KLS Rushcard, which included her own line of purple Rushcards.{{cite web|url=https://www.rushcard.com/landing/klslanding.aspx |title=Prepaid Cards - Credit, Debit, Prepaid |publisher=Rushcard |date= |accessdate=2013-10-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019171338/https://www.rushcard.com/landing/klslanding.aspx |archivedate=2013-10-19 |df= }} Simmons, a philanthropist, feels a sense of responsibility to give back to communities because of everyone in her childhood that gave her a chance to prove herself. Charitable work is not something she does for fun, she states specifically: "Whose life have you changed? Who have you helped move forward, grow, and progress?"{{Cite web|url=http://hamptons-magazine.com/kimora-lee-simmons-on-art-for-life-and-philanthropy|title=Kimora Lee Simmons on Art for Life and Philanthropy|last=Barr|first=Natalia|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} Simmons established the Kimora Lee Simmons Scholarship Fund at her high school alma mater in [[St. Louis]] to provide college tuition support for academically successful girls with financial needs and is an active member of youth advocacy organizations including Amfar, The G&P Foundation, Keep a Child Alive, Hetrick-Martin Institute and Rush Philanthropic where she is on the Board of Directors. The mayor of St. Louis presented Simmons the key to the city and named March 18, 2008 "Kimora Day" in St. Louis.[http://www.apparelsearch.com/news/Articles/Events/2008/March/3.19.08_Kimora_Lee_Simmons_Launch_Saint_Louis_Fashion_Week.htm Kimora Lee Simmons Helps Launch St Louis Fashion Week]. (March 19, 2008) Apparel Search. Accessed 2009-05-05. ==Personal life== ===Relationships and children=== {{hidden|style=float:right; clear:right; width:22em; margin-left:1em; border:1px #aaa solid; |title=Children of Kimora Lee Simmons |content= * By Russell Simmons ** Ming Lee (born 2000) ** Aoki Lee (born 2002) * By Djimon Hounsou ** Kenzo Lee (born 2009) * By Tim Leissner ** Wolfe Lee (born 2015) }} [[File:Djimon hounsou kimora lee simmons push premiere.jpg|thumb|Djimon Hounsou and Kimora Lee Simmons arrive at the premiere of Push, Mann Theater, Westwood, 2009.]] Lee met [[Russell Simmons]] in November 1992 during New York City's Fashion Week. She was 17 and about to finish high school; he was 35 and a self-admitted ladies' man. The couple were married by Simmons's brother, rapper and Pentecostal minister, [[Joseph Simmons|Joseph "Reverend Run" Simmons]]" of [[Run-DMC]], on the Caribbean island of [[Saint Barthélemy|St. Bart's]] on December 20, 1998. They have two daughters, Ming Lee Simmons (born January 21, 2000) and Aoki Lee Simmons (born August 16, 2002). The couple separated in March 2006.Stephen M. Silverman with Tiffany McGee (March 31, 2006) [http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,1178541,00.html Russell, Kimora Lee Simmons Split] ''People''. Accessed 2007-12-20. In March 2008, she filed for divorce from Russell Simmons.[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/23819374/ Kimora Lee Simmons files for divorce] (March 26, 2008) ''MSNBC''. Accessed 2008-05-17. Their divorce was finalized in January 2009.[https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2009-02-26-simmons-child-support_N.htm Russell, Kimora Lee Simmons settle on child support]. (February 29, 2009). ''USA Today''. Accessed 2009-03-02. In March 2007, Simmons was dating actor and model [[Djimon Hounsou]].[http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20014140,00.html Russell Simmons Okay with Kimora & Djimon] (March 6, 2007) ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''. Accessed 2008-01-21. In the summer of 2008, Simmons and Hounsou participated in a traditional Benin commitment ceremony.{{cite news|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2009-03-09/gossip/17918062_1_kimora-lee-simmons-pregnant-gossip-girl |title=African nups for Kimora Lee Simmons and Djimon Hounsou, but are they legit? |publisher=NY Daily News |date=2009-03-09 |accessdate=2013-10-18}} On May 30, 2009, Simmons gave birth to their son, Kenzo Lee Hounsou, meaning "Three" (Kimora's third child). Sarah Michaud and Missy Ritt (May 31, 2009) [http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20282310,00.html Kimora Lee Simmons, Djimon Hounsou Have a Boy] ''People''. Accessed 2009-06-28.[http://www.nypost.com/seven/6032009/gossip/pagesix/kimora_lees_designer_baby_172333.htm Kimora Lee's Designer Baby] (June 3, 2009) ''New York Post''. Accessed 2009-06-28. Simmons and Hounsou, who were never legally married in the United States, announced their separation in November 2012.{{cite news|last=Jordan|first=Julie|title=Kimora Lee Simmons and Djimon Hounsou Separate|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20650640,00.html|accessdate=2012-11-22|newspaper=People|date=November 21, 2012}} In February 2014, Lee confirmed that she is married to former [[Goldman Sachs]] banker Tim Leissner, and had been "for a while now".https://next.ft.com/content/bff30cc0-dab8-11e5-98fd-06d75973fe09 {{cite news|last=Malec|first=Brett|title=Surprise! Kimora Lee Simmons Is Married, Weds Businessman Tim Leissner in Secret|url=http://ca.eonline.com/news/512734/surprise-kimora-lee-simmons-is-married-weds-businessman-tim-leissner-in-secret|accessdate=2014-02-19|work=E|date=February 19, 2014}} Leissner, a senior Goldman Sachs Group Inc. banker before leaving the firm in the wake of its work with Malaysia's [[1Malaysia Development Berhad scandal|embattled investment fund]], has been barred from the U.S. securities industry for failing to provide documents to a regulator. Simmons gave birth in April 2015 to a baby boy named Wolfe Lee Leissner.{{cite web|url=https://instagram.com/p/13sO2CoIE4/?taken-by=officialkimora |title=Instagram |publisher=Instagram |date= |accessdate=2015-10-27}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2015/04/14/kimora-lee-simmons-welcomes-son-wolfe/?xid=socialflow_twitter_peoplemag |title=Kimora Lee Simmons Welcomes Son Wolfe – Moms & Babies – Celebrity Babies and Kids - Moms & Babies - People.com |publisher=Celebritybabies.people.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-27}} ===Legal issues=== In July 2004, Simmons was arrested and charged with reckless driving, eluding police, driving with a broken brake light, and marijuana possession after a two-mile chase that began near the Saddle River Police Station and ended outside her estate in Saddle River, New Jersey.{{cite web|title=Kimora Lee Simmons|url= http://www.thesmokinggun.com/mugshots/celebrity/b-list/kimora-lee-simmons|work=The Smoking Gun|department=MUG SHOTS: B-List }} On August 9, 2005, Simmons pleaded guilty to the reckless driving charge and was placed on six months' probation.{{cite web|title=Kimora Lee Simmons Placed on Probation|author=Stephen M. Silverman|date=August 11, 2005|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,1092435,00.html}} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:lightsteelblue;" ! colspan=4 | Film |- style="background:#ccc;" ! Year ! Film ! Role ! Notes |- | 1993 | ''[[For Love or Money (1993 film)|For Love or Money]]'' | Model | Alternative title: ''The Concierge'' |- | 1999 | ''[[The Big Tease]]'' | Dick Miyaki's Hair Model | |- | 2002 | ''[[Brown Sugar (2002 film)|Brown Sugar]]'' | Herself | |- | 2005 | ''[[Beauty Shop]]'' | Denise | |- | 2005 | ''[[Rebound (2005 film)|Rebound]]'' | Female Reporter #1 | |- | 2006 | ''[[Waist Deep]]'' | Fencing House Lady | |- style="background:lightsteelblue;" ! colspan=4| Television |- style="background:#ccc;" ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- | 2001 | ''[[For Your Love (TV series)|For Your Love]]'' | Shamira | 1 episode |- | 2003 | ''[[America's Next Top Model]]'' | Judge | Judge for [[America's Next Top Model (cycle 1)|cycle 1]] |- | 2007–2011 | ''[[Kimora: Life in the Fab Lane]]'' | Herself | |- | 2013 | ''[[Kimora: House of Fab]]'' | Herself | |- style="background:lightsteelblue;" ! colspan=4 | Video games |- style="background:#ccc;" ! [[Pharrell]]) | [[Chris Robinson (director)|Chris Robinson]] |} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.kimoraleesimmons.com/ Official website] * [http://blog.justfab.com/author/kimora-lee-simmons/ Kimora Lee Simmons blog posts] on [[JustFab]] * {{IMDb name|0497686}} * {{Fashionmodel}} * {{fashiondesigner|id=kimora-lee-simmons}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080602053123/http://www.osmoz.com/News-Trends/Interviews/Kimora-Lee-Simmons Simmons' interview at OSMOZ] {{America's Next Top Model}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Simmons, Kimora Lee}} [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Actresses from St. Louis]] [[Category:African-American businesspeople]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:African-American fashion designers]] [[Category:American fashion designers]] [[Category:African-American female models]] [[Category:American female models]] [[Category:African-American models]] [[Category:American models of Japanese descent]] [[Category:American actresses of Japanese descent]] [[Category:American self-help writers]] [[Category:American television producers]] [[Category:Women television producers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Participants in American reality television series]] [[Category:American television actresses]] [[Category:African-American actresses]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:Transcendental Meditation practitioners]]

page.title: List of The Voice of Ireland finalists (series 2)

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''The Voice of Ireland'' finalists (series 2)}} The [[The Voice of Ireland (series 2)|second series]] of the talent show, in [[Ireland]], '''''[[The Voice of Ireland]]''''' which began broadcasting on 6 January 2013. The coaches are [[Niall Breslin|Bressie]], [[Kian Egan]] of [[Westlife]], [[Sharon Corr]] of the Irish pop-rock band [[The Corrs]] and [[Jamelia]].
The winner of the series was [[Keith Hanley]] of Team Jamelia and runner up [[Kelly Mongan]] of Team Kian.
==Team Jamelia==
===Keith Hanley=== {{main|Keith Hanley}} '''Keith Hanley''' (born August 15, 1993) is an Irish singer from [[Charleville, County Cork|Charleville]], [[County Cork]]. Keith's coach on the show was [[R&B]] singer [[Jamelia]] who was making her debut season on the show. He won a recording contract with [[Universal Music]] he performed his winning song "[[Beggin']]". He also performed 'Jigsaw' with [[Ryan Sheridan (musician)|Ryan Sheridan]] that night.<ref>[http://corkindependent.com/20130429/news/keith-takes-voice-title-S64075.html Keith Hanley from Charleville has been named the Voice of Ireland 2013.]</ref> Hanley was crowned the winner of the second series.
===Wayne Beatty===
===Dylan Powell===
===Roisín Carlin===
===Jennifer Moore===
===Sophie Rischar===
==Team Kian==
===Kelly Mongan=== '''Kelly Mongan''' is an Irish singer from [[Fermoy]], [[County Cork]]. Kelly's coach on the show was [[Westlife]] singer [[Kian Egan]]. Mongan was crowned the runner-up of the second series. She is an [[Irish Traveller]].
===Shane McLaughlin=== '''Ray Scully'''
===Karl Sheridan===
===Daryl Phillips===
===Shannon Murphy===
===Katy Anna Mohan===
===Sinead O'Brien=== '''Kian O'Holland'''
===Jennifer Moore===
===Terri O'Reilly===
==References== {{reflist|2}}

page.title: List of U.S. counties named after women

revision.text:
This is a '''list of U.S. counties which are named after women'''. Items may be listed in more than one category.
== Locals and settlers == *[[Ada County, Idaho]]: Ada is named for [[Ada Riggs]], the first pioneer child born in the area and the daughter of [[Boise, Idaho]] cofounder [[H.C. Riggs]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idaho.gov/aboutidaho/county/ada/|work=Idaho.gov|title=Ada County|accessdate=7 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150321113602/http://www.idaho.gov/aboutidaho/county/ada|archivedate=21 March 2015|df=}}</ref> *[[Dare County, North Carolina]]: Dare is named for [[Virginia Dare]], the first English child born in the New World who disappeared with the [[Lost Colony]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.darenc.com/general/mainabout.asp|title=About Dare County|work=Dare County|accessdate=7 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403130938/http://www.darenc.com/general/mainabout.asp|archivedate=3 April 2012|df=}}</ref> *[[East Feliciana Parish, Louisiana]]: East Feliciana is allegedly named for [[Felicite de Gálvez]], the wife of [[Bernardo de Gálvez]], a [[Spain|Spanish]] governor of the [[Louisiana Territory]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.felicianatourism.org/history.htm|title=History of East Feliciana Parish|work=Feliciana Tourism|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012201448/http://www.felicianatourism.org/history.htm|archivedate=2016-10-12|df=}}</ref> *[[Florence County, South Carolina]]: Florence is named for [[Florence Harllee]], a daughter of [[W. W. Harllee]], a president of the [[Wilmington and Manchester Railroad]].<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9V1IAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA127#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=The Origin of Certain Place Names in the United States | publisher=Govt. Print. Off. | author=Gannett, Henry | year=1905 | pages=127}}</ref> *[[Grainger County, Tennessee]]: Grainger is named for [[Mary Grainger Blount]], the wife of [[William Blount]], the only governor of the [[Southwest Territory]] (modern [[Tennessee]]).<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9V1IAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA141#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=The Origin of Certain Place Names in the United States | publisher=Govt. Print. Off. | author=Gannett, Henry | year=1905 | pages=141}}</ref> *[[Hart County, Georgia]]: Hart is named for [[Nancy Hart]], a woman sharpshooter and patriot in the [[American Revolutionary War]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://georgia.gov/cities-counties/hart-county|title=Hart Country|work=Georgia.gov|accessdate=8 January 2015}}</ref> *[[Josephine County, Oregon]]: Josephine is named for [[Virginia "Josephine" Rollins]], the first European-American woman to settle in southern [[Oregon]]. *[[Marshall County, Oklahoma]]: Marshall is named for the mother of [[George A. Henshaw]], a delegate to the state constitutional convention, Marshall having been her maiden name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/M/MA030.html|title=Marshall County|work=Oklahoma Historical Society Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History & Culture|accessdate=8 January 2015}}</ref> *[[Merrick County, Nebraska]]: Merrick is named after [[Elvira Merrick]], wife of [[Henry W. DePuy]], a territorial legislator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usgennet.org/usa/ne/topic/resources/OLLibrary/Maps_Atlas/nebplacenames/placename6.html#merrick|title=Nebraska Place Names (1925)|work= NEGenWeb Project|accessdate=8 January 2015}}</ref> *[[Wake County, North Carolina]]: Wake is named for [[Margaret Wake (North Carolina)|Margaret Wake]], a [[London]] heiress and the wife of [[William Tryon]], a colonial governor of [[North Carolina]].<ref>{{cite web|work=United States National Park Service|title=Joel Lane House|url=http://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/raleigh/lan.htm}}</ref> *[[West Feliciana Parish, Louisiana]]: West Feliciana is allegedly named for [[Felicite de Gálvez]], the wife of [[Bernardo de Gálvez]], a [[Spain|Spanish]] governor of the [[Louisiana Territory]].
== Native Americans == *[[Angelina County, Texas]]: Angelina is named for Angelina, a [[Hasinai]] [[Native American (U.S.)|Native American]] woman who assisted early Spanish missionaries and was named ''Angelina'' by them.<ref>{{cite web|title=About|work=Angelina County website|url=http://www.angelinacounty.net/about}}</ref> *[[Marinette County, Wisconsin]]: Marinette is named for [[Marinette (trader)|Marinette]], a 19th-century trader who was the daughter of a [[French-Canadian]] trapper and a [[Menominee]] woman.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lettersforgeorge.blogspot.com/2011/11/queen-marinette.html|title=Letters for George: Queen Marinette|last=L|first=David|date=2011-11-03|website=Letters for George|access-date=2016-04-20}}</ref> *[[Pocahontas County, West Virginia]] (Established as Pocahontas County, Virginia): Pocahontas is named for [[Pocahontas]], the famous [[Native American (U.S.)|Native American]] who played a leading role in the history of the first permanent English settlements in [[North America]]. *[[Pocahontas County, Iowa]]: Pocahontas is named for [[Pocahontas]], the famous [[Native American (U.S.)|Native American]] who played a leading role in the history of the first permanent English settlements in [[North America]]. *[[Tama County, Iowa]]: Tama is named for any of several [[Native American (U.S.)|Native American]] chiefs or chief's wives, over which there is dispute. *[[Tippah County, Mississippi]]: Tippah is named for [[Tippah]], wife of [[Pontotoc, Mississippi|Pontotoc]], an important [[Chickasaw]] leader.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qXonmIMRI4oC|title=The Papers of Jefferson Davis: June 1841--July 1846|last=Davis|first=Jefferson|date=1975-02-01|publisher=LSU Press|isbn=9780807100820|language=en}}</ref> *[[Winona County, Minnesota]]: Winona is named after Wenonah (which means oldest daughter in Dakota), a [[Lakota people|Dakota]] woman of distinction who was a cousin of the last of three chiefs named Wabasha. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://diversityfoundation.org/HomecomingToExploreRoles.html|title=Homecoming To Explore Roles of American Indian Women|last=Thompson|first=Michael Allen|website=diversityfoundation.org|access-date=2016-04-20}}</ref>
== Famous women == *[[Barton County, Kansas]]: Barton is named for [[Clara Barton]], the pioneering American nurse who organized the [[American Red Cross]].<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o8X5krq3fP8C&pg=PA153#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Kansas: A Cyclopedia of State History, Embracing Events, Institutions, Industries, Counties, Cities, Towns, Prominent Persons, Etc. | publisher=Standard Publishing Company | author=Blackmar, Frank Wilson | year=1912 | pages=153}}</ref> *[[Bremer County, Iowa]]: Bremer is named for [[Fredrika Bremer]], a Swedish novelist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.co.bremer.ia.us/bremer-county/history.aspx|title= Bremer County History |publisher=Bremer County, Iowa|accessdate= May 6, 2011}}</ref>
== Titled noblewomen and queens == *[[Amelia County, Virginia]]: Amelia is named for [[Princess Amelia of Great Britain]], daughter of [[George II of Great Britain|George II]]. *[[Anne Arundel County, Maryland]]: Anne Arundel is named for [[Anne Arundell]], the wife of [[Cecil Calvert, 2nd Baron Baltimore]] and daughter of [[Thomas Arundell, 1st Baron Arundell of Wardour]]. *[[Augusta County, Virginia]]: Augusta is named for [[Augusta of Saxe-Gotha]], wife of [[Frederick, Prince of Wales]] and mother of [[George III of Great Britain]]. *[[Caroline County, Maryland]]: Caroline is named for Lady [[Caroline Eden]], the daughter of [[Charles Calvert, 5th Baron Baltimore]], sister of [[Frederick Calvert, 6th Baron Baltimore]], and wife of [[Sir Robert Eden, 1st Baronet, of Maryland|Robert Eden]], the last colonial governor of [[Maryland]]. *[[Caroline County, Virginia]]: Caroline is named for [[Caroline of Ansbach]], wife of [[George II of Great Britain]]. *[[Charlotte County, Virginia]]: Charlotte is named for [[Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz]], wife of [[George III of Great Britain]]. *[[Dutchess County, New York]]: Dutchess is named for [[Mary of Modena]], the [[Duke of York|Duchess of York]] and wife of the future King [[James II of England]]. *[[Isabella County, Michigan]]: Isabella is named for Queen [[Isabella I of Castile]], who patronized [[Christopher Columbus]]. *[[King and Queen County, Virginia]]: King and Queen is named for King [[William III of England]] and Queen [[Mary II of England]]. *[[Louisa County, Virginia]]: Louisa is named for [[Louise of Great Britain|Princess Louise]], daughter of [[George II of Great Britain]]. *[[Mecklenburg County, North Carolina]]: Mecklenburg is named for [[Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz]], wife of [[George III of Great Britain]]. *[[Mecklenburg County, Virginia]]: Mecklenburg is named for [[Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz]], wife of [[George III of Great Britain]]. *[[Queen Anne's County, Maryland]]: Queen Anne's is named for [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain]]. *[[Queens County, New York]]: Queens is named for [[Catherine of Braganza]], Queen of England and the wife of [[Charles II of England]].
== Saints == *[[St. Helena Parish, Louisiana]]: St. Helena is named for [[Saint]] [[Helena of Constantinople]], the mother of [[Constantine I of the Roman Empire|Constantine the Great]]. *[[St. Lucie County, Florida]]: St. Lucie was named for the [[Spanish Florida|Spanish-era]] [[Ais (tribe)|Ais]] town of [[Jonathan Dickinson#Santa Lucea|Santa Lucea]], presumed to have been named by the Spanish for [[Saint Lucy|Saint Lucie of Syracuse]]. *[[Ste. Genevieve County, Missouri]]: Ste. Genevieve is named after [[Genevieve|Sainte Genevieve]], the patron saint of [[Paris]]. *[[Santa Barbara County, California]]: Santa Barbara is named for [[Saint Barbara]], patroness of fire. *[[Santa Clara County, California]]: Santa Clara is named for [[Mission Santa Clara]], which was in turn named for [[Saint Clara de Asís]].
== Aspects of the Virgin Mary == *[[Assumption Parish, Louisiana]]: Assumption is named for the [[Assumption of Mary]] into heaven. *[[Dolores County, Colorado]]: Dolores is named for the [[Dolores River]], originally ''Rio de Nuestra Senora de los Dolores'', or, in [[English language|English]], ''River of our Lady of Sorrows''. *[[Guadalupe County, New Mexico]]: Guadalupe is named for [[Our Lady of Guadalupe]], the [[patron saint]] of the [[Americas]]. *[[Los Angeles County, California]]: Los Angeles is named for the fact that [[Gaspar de Portolà]]'s explorers reached what was then the Native American village of [[Yangna]] on August 2, 1769, the [[feast day]] of ''Nuestra Señora la Reina de Los Angeles de Porciúncula'' ({{lang-en|Our Lady, Queen of the Angels of Porciúncula}}). *[[St. Mary Parish, Louisiana]]: St. Mary is named for the [[Blessed Virgin Mary]], the mother of [[Jesus]]. *[[St. Mary's County, Maryland]]: St. Mary's is named for the [[Blessed Virgin Mary]], the mother of [[Jesus]].
== Fictional == *[[Attala County, Mississippi]]: Attala is named for [[Attala (Native American)|Attala]] or Atala, a fictional [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] heroine from a story by [[François-René de Chateaubriand]]. *[[Evangeline Parish, Louisiana]]: Evangeline is named after the heroine of the poem ''[[Evangeline]]'' by [[Henry Wadsworth Longfellow]]. *[[Leelanau County, Michigan]]: Leelanau is named after "''Leelinau''", a name given to Native American women in the stories of [[Henry Schoolcraft|Henry Rowe Schoolcraft]].
== Counties indirectly named for women == *[[Doña Ana County, New Mexico]]: Doña Ana is named for its first [[county seat]] of [[Doña Ana, New Mexico]], which in turn was named for Doña [[Ana Robledo]], a 17th-century woman known for her charitable giving. *[[Fluvanna County, Virginia]]: Fluvanna is named for an archaic term for the [[James River (Virginia)|James River]], ''fluv anna'' or ''River of Anne''. *[[Haines Borough, Alaska]]: Haines Borough is named after [[Haines, Alaska]], which is named in turn for [[Mrs. F. E. Haines]], the community leader who raised funds for a religious mission to the local [[Tlingit|Chilkat]] [[Native American (U.S.)|Native American]] tribe. *[[Judith Basin County, Montana]]: Judith Basin is named for the [[Judith River]], which in turn is named for [[Julia Hancock]], the sweetheart and future wife of [[William Clark (explorer)|William Clark]] of the [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]], who discovered the river; the misspelling is because Clark mistook her name to be Judith. *[[Santa Rosa County, Florida]]: Santa Rosa is named for [[Santa Rosa Island, Florida|Santa Rosa Island]], which in turn is named for Santa Rosa de Viterbo ([[Saint Rose of Viterbo]]), a Catholic saint who lived in the thirteenth century.
== Counties possibly named for women == *[[Culpeper County, Virginia]]: Culpeper is named for one of three members of the Colepeper family, of which two were women: [[Thomas Colepeper, 2nd Baron Colepeper of Thoresway]], a colonial governor of Virginia; his first wife [[Margaretta van Hesse]], called Margaret, Lady Colepeper; or their daughter, Thomas's heir and only surviving issue, [[Catherine Colepeper]]. *[[Elmore County, Idaho]]: Elmore is named for the [[Ida Elmore mines]], which may have been named for a woman named Ida Elmore. *[[Ida County, Iowa]]: Ida is named for possibly [[Ida Smith]], the first European-American child born in the county. *[[Louisa County, Iowa]]: Louisa is named for either [[Louisa Massey]] of [[Dubuque, Iowa]], who, according to legend, killed the murderer of her brother; or [[Louisa County, Virginia]]. *[[Maries County, Missouri]]: Maries is named for the [[Maries River]], which may be named after one or more Maries. * [[St. Clair County, Michigan]]: St. Clair is named for either [[Arthur St. Clair]], the first governor of the [[Northwest Territory]]; or [[Saint]] [[Clare of Assisi]], on whose [[feast day]] [[Lake Saint Clair (North America)|Lake St. Clair]] was discovered. *[[Tama County, Iowa]]: Tama is named for any of several [[Native American (U.S.)|Native American]] chiefs or chief's wives, over which there is dispute.
== See also == * [[County (United States)]] * [[Lists of U.S. county name etymologies]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{USCountyLists}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of U.S. Counties Named After Women}} [[Category:U.S. county name etymologies]] [[Category:Lists of women|United States Counties]] [[Category:Lists of counties of the United States|Women]] [[Category:Lists of things named after people|U.S. counties named after women]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer | name = | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = Louise Arnold (writer) with books.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Louise Arnold | birth_date = | birth_place = Morden, Surrey | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = | language = | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = University of Kent | alma_mater = | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = * Golden & Grey (An Unremarkable Boy and a Rather Remarkable Ghost) (2005) *Golden & Grey: The Nightmares That Ghosts Have (2006) *Golden & Grey: A Good Day for Haunting (2008) | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} {{Portal |Children's literature}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{for|the baseball player|Louise Arnold (baseball)}} '''Louise Arnold''' is an English writer of [[Children's literature]]. Her published works to date include the [[Grey Arthur]] series of novels. ==Biography== ===Personal life=== Arnold was born in [[Morden]], [[Surrey]]. She wrote her first poem aged four, and lived in [[Bognor Regis]] until she passed her A-Level exams. She graduated from the [[University of Kent]] in 2003 with a 2.1 in drama.{{Citation | title = Author: Louise Arnold | url = http://www.hodderchildrens.co.uk/Louise-Arnold_profile.htm | publisher = hodderschildrens.co.uk | accessdate = 8 December 2012}} While studying there, she was diagnosed with [[dyslexia]]. She now lives in [[Canterbury]], Kent.{{Citation | last = Oakes | first = Keily | title = BBC winner realises writing dream | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/4672991.stm |publisher=BBC News | date = 13 July 2005 | accessdate = 30 December 2008 }} ===Professional life=== In 2003 the BBC News website launched a competition to find "The next [[J. K. Rowling]]". Entrants were invited to submit the first paragraph of a children's book. A selection of these was then put to an online public vote, which Arnold subsequently won with her entry, entitled "A not very frightening ghost". She was signed by an agent, Kate Jones,{{Citation | last = | first = | title = Kate Jones | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1577748/Kate-Jones.html | date = 7 February 2008 | accessdate = 30 December 2008 | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph}}{{Citation | last = Franklin | first = Andrew | title = Kate Jones: Literary agent with flawless taste | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/kate-jones-literary-agent-with-flawless-taste-778593.html | date = 6 February 2008 | accessdate = 30 December 2008 | location=London | work=The Independent}} which then led to a publishing deal, with her first novel ''The Invisible Friend'' being released in 2005.{{Citation | last = Craig | first = Amanda | title = Me and my shadow | url = http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/books/article543985.ece |work=The Times |location=UK | date = 16 July 2005 | accessdate = 30 December 2008 }}
"I was contacted by an agent and had to go for meetings which was very daunting because the industry was all new to me and I had little clue how it all worked...But I got lucky with the people I met and I realise how lucky I am to have this opportunity."
"I was given a deadline of a year to write the book, which I delivered on time. I'm a bit of daydreamer so I needed that deadline to get me down to working."
==Published works== * ''[[Golden & Grey (An Unremarkable Boy and a Rather Remarkable Ghost)]]'' (2005) * ''[[Golden & Grey: The Nightmares That Ghosts Have]]'' (2006) * ''[[Golden & Grey: A Good Day for Haunting]]'' (2008) In England, the title instead of An Unremarkable Boy and a Rather Remarkable Ghost is: * ''[[The Invisible Friend]]'' and the title for The Nightmares That Ghosts Have is: * ''[[The Ghost School]]'' ==Interviews== * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/blast/writing/people/louise_arnold.shtml Spotlight on Louise Arnold] ==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} {{refend}} ==External links== * [http://www.theinvisiblefriend.com/ The Invisible Friend] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arnold, Louise}} [[Category:English children's writers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People diagnosed with dyslexia]] {{UK-child-writer-stub}}
